turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: Yes...

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: You want me to wear white for you? You must be madder than I thought...

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: But ELLEN, I told you I have stopped...

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: But for how long - what will set you off again? You'll be walking down the street and some girl will be wearing a white hat - and that will be it - back on the merry go round...

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: Out - I may be some time

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: We've got nothing to talk about

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: LESLIE I'm sorry - I - I didn't know what to think

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: I thought we had a relationship built on trust - and you just slap me in the face...

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I am sorry...

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: LESLIE?  Is that good enough?

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: Yes - I suppose so...

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: ELLEN, would you like a cup - there's plenty in the pot

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: No thanks -

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: First finish your tea...

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: He doesn't need to...

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Why did you let him in?

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: What was I supposed to do?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I don't like sugar

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: There isn't that much - you didn't even taste it - What's wrong - don't you like my tea?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: It's not that - I just don't want any sugar

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: Why whats wrong with the sugar -

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I haven't been using it recently LESLIE

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: CRAP! - I wish I had taken a photo of your face when I gave some to that DETECTIVE - What's wrong ELLEN - you look pale - maybe you have been eating the wrong kind of foods lately - it could be food poisoning?

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: whats wrong...what have I done wrong?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Nothing LESLIE - I just think we should wait...

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: WAIT FOR WHAT!?

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: I don't want either of us to come to any harm - please...

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: You killed my friend!

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: I loved you ELLEN - why did you do this?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: It's what you would do to me

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Don't you want me now LESLIE

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: No - I'll have you after

turns.speaker: MIK
turns.text: I'm sorry, I couldn't - when is she due?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Well, what do you think?

turns.speaker: MIK
turns.text: I don't know - it's your house ELLEN

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Yes - but you live here too - If it were your house?

turns.speaker: MIK
turns.text: I think he's fine - I don't know why you have this thing about men - it would be nice to have a guy in the house for a change - I don't think he would hurt a fly.

turns.speaker: MIK
turns.text: What's wrong with you?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I would prefer it if you kept away from LESLIE

turns.speaker: MIK
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: You heard me - keep away from him

turns.speaker: MIK
turns.text: You don't own him you know - you can't tell me not to see him!

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Yes I can...

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I want you out now

turns.speaker: MIK
turns.text: Leave!? Who the hell do you think you are?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I'm your landlady

turns.speaker: MIK
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I had an accident - I fell down stairs...

turns.speaker: MIK
turns.text: Is LESLIE here?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: No he had to - he's just - he's out...

turns.speaker: MIK
turns.text: He saved my life you know - has he told you...

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: It's been what, three years?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: What's this all about?

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: So have you seen hubby recently ELLEN?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: What brings the rats out of the sewers?

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: I'm here about the so called disappearance of your husband - It's best if we let old bones lie. Know what I mean?  I'm working on the WHITE ANGEL case now - and I've got to check all known murderers or suspected murderers for the last five years... And that means you...So where were you last THURSDAY afternoon around five...

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: You think I'm the WHITE ANGEL?

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: It did give me a chance to meet you again ELLEN - It's all routine you understand...So where were you?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: At home alone - where were you?

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: As it happens, I was at home alone - maybe we could solve each others problems?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Get out...

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: I'd watch her mate - she has thing for men - they disappear near her.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I think you had better leave

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: I'm really very sorry - I was banking on this coming through, because it's only five minutes from my surgery...

turns.speaker: MIK
turns.text: Surgery? Are you a doctor?

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: No - a dentist

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: Just put it in my room

turns.speaker: MIK
turns.text: No worries

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to shout...

turns.speaker: MIK
turns.text: Don't worry about it -

turns.speaker: MIK
turns.text: You're a novelist - why didn't you tell me?

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: And not just any novelist - a great novelist - it was an impressive piece of work ELLEN...

turns.speaker: MIK
turns.text: Her husband left her

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: Oh...

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: I thought it was you - how are you?

turns.speaker: MIK
turns.text: I'm good - I was just making a delivery near here, so I thought I would see if you were about...

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: Yes, come on in...

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: That's good

turns.speaker: MIK
turns.text: I'd really like it if you would come round some time - Then I could cook you a meal - what do you say...

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: Yes, that would be nice - I'll call round some time...

turns.speaker: MIK
turns.text: Good - I've got to dash -  Say that I said hello to ELLEN for me would you...

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: Yes - of course.

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: Dr STECKLER?

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: Yes...?

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: INSPECTOR DAVE TAYLOR - Scotland yard ...Can I have a word?

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: Dead?

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: Or was it, she wished he was dead - that's it - I believe he left the country with another woman - all rather sordid.

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: So she didn't mention anything more about it?

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: No - she isn't in any trouble is she?

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: Oh no sir - just making some enquiries...Just tell her that INSPECTOR TAYLOR called on you - she'll understand

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: I'll be sure to...

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: I shouldn't really - I'm not your surgeon...

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: Who said anything about surgery...It'll only take a moment.

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: Sugar?

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: Yes - one please.

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: ANGEL...

turns.speaker: STECKLER
turns.text: Yes, sorry - He's here to make sure that you are alright

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Come on, bro. Spare yourself the humiliation, the degradation...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You and your pep talks.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Don't get me wrong. We can salivate over all the Christy Malones of our lives. Wishing we could devour them like melt-in-your-mouth filet mignon. But we're strictly hamburger guys. Ground chuck, sixty eight percent lean, is about the best we can hope for.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That's Charlie.  My best friend. He's into beef analogies, partly because he's a butcher's son, and partly because, well, he's just into beef analogies. What can I say? He's also a photographer...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I genuinely think she wants me. I feel a vibe.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: That vibe is from your wrist, pal. You've been over-tenderizing your meat, again.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: See? Did you see that?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: She smiles at everyone, Ted.  She's like a newborn with gas.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: The only chick more untouchable than Christy Malone is Miss April.  "Hi, my name's Ginger. I love tofu burgers, rainy nights, and riding bareback.  My biggest turn-off is cell phones during sex." Here's a tip:  set it on VIBRATE, honey, and don't be stingy with the lube.  Don't knock it till you tried it.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Were you always this sick?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: One thing for sure, Christy Malone ain't lookin THAT good naked.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Someday, I'll find out.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You have a better chance of being hit by a Mack truck with a refrigerated cargo bed full of sirloin tip.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I defy your hamburger theory of life, and all of the unfulfilled hopes and dreams it represents.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: That's crazy talk.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I defy any and all limits.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Don't do it, Ted. Don't do it.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Any time, any day, a man can completely reinvent himself.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Think about it...Long tunnel, bright lights, it's full of vaginal symbolism.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Poor Freud, turning in his grave.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Seriously, it's like we're being reborn. We really could reinvent ourselves here, just like you said. Nobody knows about your massive humiliation.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Nobody knows about your mental retardation.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Nobody knows you barfed during junior high school graduation.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Nobody knows about your constant masturbation.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: And nobody knows you're a virgin!  Aw, who are we kidding...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: What are the odds of there being ANOTHER Ted Nelson on our flight?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Astronomical.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Who the hell was your father?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Well, Dad said...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ...A bouncer? Are you serious?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Maybe he got promoted.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: This is the life, baby. We get ourselves some tail and we're talking SPRING BREAK!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Cut it out, before you break something!

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: For a guy about to try his first Dom Perignon, you are extremely uptight.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Don't you know anything about limo etiquette? Everything in here is included for our pleasure.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Wait a second, I thought we were hamburger guys.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: And like every hamburger guy knows, when you get your one big chance at the good life, you abuse every second of it until they figure out you don't belong there and kick your sorry ass out.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I can't believe that's your mother. We're talking babe-a-licious chub fest, right here in the 501's.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Perv.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: This is like my every wet dream come true.  I don't even care that you're here, too, bro.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Be cool. Fake it if you have to.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I wonder how many of them will be at the orgy tonight?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: This isn't some 80's porno film, you dip shit. There are no wild sex orgies.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Oh. Well. Maybe not yet.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Not ever. Never.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You kiss your mother with that mouth?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I'd kiss your mother with this mouth. I mean, if she wasn't, you know...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: So far away? In Xenia?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Yeah, whatever.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Check this out.  Hurry!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I better go, Dad.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Hurry.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What is it now?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Check it out!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Don't tell me.  Another vision of incomparable beauty?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Beauty? No. We're talking GODDESS.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I get it now. You and me. We're dead.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Dead?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Our plane crashed. In the Grand Canyon. A big fiery explosion. We never made it to L.A. They needed dental records to identify us. And this place. This. Actually. Is. Heaven.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Then there must be a whole room, made completely of chocolate.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: And some really fast cars.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Don't be such a pansy. All of this is YOURS.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It's a lot to digest. Imagine how you'd feel.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I'd feel like staying up all night! Forever! Or at least till I got the LAY of the land, SO TO SPEAK.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I feel like I'm entering a forbidden tomb...

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: ...where they get all the really good porno channels on cable.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh, how inappropriate is that!

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Take a whiff of heaven.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: How would you like it if I did that to your mother's panties?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I'd call you a sick, twisted fuck. But this is different.  She wasn't your mother mother--

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Give me those!

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: A couple of boys fighting over a pair of red silk panties is nothing compared to what he's seen.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yeah, he's probably been serving cocktails, SO TO SPEAK, at the orgies.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You're late, bro!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Sorry. Ginger got a little, you know, enthusiastic.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You'll never believe who's in there.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It better not be my Aunt Trudy.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I feel like I've just been hit by a Mack truck.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: With a refrigerated cargo bed full of sirloin tip.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I thought I loved her.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Chicks are like buses. If you miss one, don't sweat it. There's another coming 'round the corner.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Hell yes, all hundred and seventeen of 'em!

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: No, leave one. Somebody's grandmother might want one.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: And while you're at it, I'll take ten dozen of those puppies with the springy heads.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I love those springy head puppies!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Get them together.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Brilliant!  Molly, give me all you've got.  For Merk.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Holy stinkers, what were you thinking?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: We wanted to challenge the notions of classic beauty. We wanted to showcase women throughout the world.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Next time, make sure you put a barf bag in the centerfold.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You got everything you ever wanted.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Except the girl. The only one that really mattered.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Naked girls, wild sex, video games. No wonder it's called "Heaven."

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: This is a fun place...but we don't usually come here until after the orgies.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Never say never.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Oh, god.  Look. Look.

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: Every one of these women thinks she should be the next Angel of the Month. It's your job, Ted, to decide which of them is right.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Let me get this straight...

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: If it isn't straight by now, son, you probably should see a doctor.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: These are real, live women?

turns.speaker: UNCLE BILLY
turns.text: We don't generally feature blow-up dolls in our magazine. But hey, if you think there's a market for it.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: God, I love being dead.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: What gives, Don Corleone?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: We reinvented ourselves.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: New Hushpuppies don't make a new man.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You've obviously never had your dogs nestled in thousand dollar Italian loafers.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: That explains the emptiness that haunts me.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Jealousy is so unattractive.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Not bad for a hack. He has a future in yellow journalism.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: He kicked major ass and you know it.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Wouldn't it be awesome if we were about to say the exact same thing?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: From your lips, to God's ears.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: You go first.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Ladies first.  I insist.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Well. The prom's coming up.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: And I was wondering.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: If you don't have...I mean...

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Teddy? Would you please please please take me to the prom?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: SHUT UP!  Are you serious? Of course I will...of course.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Ted, have you lost your mind?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You like me. I like you. I guess it's pretty obvious to everyone.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: I don't LIKE you. We're JUST FRIENDS.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: But that smile.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Oh, Ted, DUH.  I smile at everyone since I got my braces off.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: So you'll think about it?

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: You really don't get it, do you? I am genetically programmed to desire a big, buff, manly man who can defend and provide for me and my yet to be conceived offspring! It's, like, a caveman thing!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: So that's a maybe?

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: The answer is NEVER, Ted, NEVER. Except maybe in your dreams.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Great jacket, Teddy Bear.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yeah? You like?

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Makes your shoulders look so big and broad.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Hi, Teddy Bear.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Christy?  You want to be in "Heaven?"

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: I turned eighteen over spring break. I'm eligible.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: I thought I'd be nervous, but you sure know how to make a girl feel relaxed, Teddy Bear.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I do? I mean, yeah, I do.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: I have to admit, I am so totally turned on. We should do it. Now.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Do it?

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: You know...take the pictures?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I remember the first time you walked into Mrs. Temple's class in 2nd grade. Blue gingham dress. Blond ponytail.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Which you pulled, hard!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That was code for "I like you."

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Remember dress up day?  You and Charlie lifting skirts during recess.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I miss those days, when schoolyard sexual harassment was without consequence.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Things change. Now I'm taking off my clothes...all by myself.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You have changed since second grade.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: I mean, what do you think?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You expect me to think at a time like this? There isn't a drop of blood in my brain.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Oh, Teddy Bear, you're funny.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: I was always too shy to admit how much I liked you.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Come on, I was hamburger. You were porterhouse.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Maybe on the outside. But inside, deep down, I've always been dripping with special sauces.  Are you hungry?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: God, you are so hot.

turns.speaker: CHRISTY
turns.text: Then you better get in the water, before you get burned.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: We have a truckload of strawberries arriving on Tuesday morning.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: We own a small family grocery store.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: We can't accept it.  It's much too expensive. Right, dear?

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Of course, dumpling. Its very nice of Ted but...

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Sweetheart, what is it?

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: I always wanted Craftsman tools. He even got me the limited edition Buckeye colors.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Oh, honey. We can't accept this extravagance.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Ted, we put a lot of love in our business.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: We wanted you and Jimmy to have it someday. Something real and honest.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: We love our lives just the way they are.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: You have to understand. This was a big shock, for all of us. One minute you're our little boy, of whom we could not be more proud. The next minute you're the owner of this whole pornographic empire.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: But that doesn't make you the boss of everything, son.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Don't you see how your self involvement and lack of humility are affecting the whole family?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: We're not ashamed of you, Teddy. We don't approve of the magazine or the models or the so-called "flesh parties" you attend. But we can get past all that.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: We miss you. We miss our son.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: We miss our family.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: We think you should give up the magazine. Sell it. Let someone else run it. Whatever it takes.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: We want you to go to college, find a career you love, marry a nice girl from a nice family, and live happily ever after.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: We understand your disappointment, Teddy. Christy is a pretty, sexy, provocative, voluptuous...  We...uh...we understand your disappointment.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It's my private business! Mine!

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: I remember spring break of my senior year.  Seems like a lifetime ago.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Dad, please.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Grandpa was so strong back then. Working from the crack of dawn. So proud of his peaches.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Remember how you struggled through that whole facts of life talk and then found out I knew more than you?

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: You're way ahead of me again?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It was the year of the rhizopus rot. Grandpa almost lost the farm. You sacrificed your dream to go to the prize hog festival. And in the end you saved the peaches and you didn't have to slaughter your sow.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: The lesson being?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Sometimes you have to do stuff you don't want to do. It's all part of growing up. And it usually works out peachy in the end.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: I'm getting so good at this.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You guys are my parents.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Of course we are.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: They didn't want me when I was born. Why should I care...

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Son.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Well, why should I?

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: They had a rough life. Your father was a bouncer. Your mother was, well, a two-bit stripper. There was no place for a baby.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I guess.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: They did do one great thing. They gave us our boy.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Be a sport. How bad could spring break in Los Angeles be?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I guess we could go to Disneyland or something.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Think of it as a rite of passage to manhood.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Like one of those "National Geographic" specials with the topless chicks?

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Whatever helps you cope.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I guess it's better than having tribal patterns carved in my face.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: There ya go. Always remember, focus on the peach...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: ...not the pit.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Ted, it's your dad.  I have a question for you.  I don't know how to put it tactfully. You know I'm lousy with words.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Just say it, Dad.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: I know they were simple people, but did this trip help your college fund at all?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Dad, let's just say I can buy anything I want in the whole bookstore. Including the bookstore.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Well, good. Every little bit helps.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Finally, some gratitude.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: We're grateful, Ted. It's not that. Those Craftsman tools...they're a dream come true.
